transcripts.text: Thank you.  Child trafficking is prevalent.  It's a daily thing.  We watch it every day.  We're involved in the rescue and the rehabilitation of those children.

When I first met Andrew, he was telling us about different dreams that he had, the things that he hoped to accomplish in the future.  He talked about his love for soccer and how he wanted to be able to play one day.

Andrew is a fighter.  He has a spirit in him that wants to get better.  That has helped him a lot to get to this far.  Hundreds of more that I have personally witnessed, I have personally worked with, have been killed, mutilated, stabbed.  They have died.  We live with it and we try to do something, but the issue seems pretty big.  So Jessica contacted us and said, hey, I've talked to the doctor and the doctor is so happy to help.  So put me in touch with the doctor and we started communicating, sending details.  Doctor asked us all the questions.  We were able to come and received by Dr.  Keith and hosted us and looked after us.  And that's how we're here.

As Andrew came to the United States and as we further evaluated him, his care was beyond my scope of orthopedics.  We made a phone call down to the Shriners Hospital, and in a very short period of time and quite efficiently, they opened their arms to their staff, their administration, and the facility to accomplish the care that Andrew needed to give him his best chance of improving his function and having a much more enjoyable life.
We're grateful for the doctors that have stepped in.  They've done it pro bono.  They've given their time, but even more, they've given their hearts and their emotions.
We are very thankful to OUR for their partnership in the care and support of Andrew.  We had hit a snag on what to do for him.

He will be non-weight-bearing for an extended period of time, several weeks until the bones have healed.  The tendons need to reattach themselves, and once that happens, we can then start stretching or allow him to actively start moving the extremities where the tendons have been lengthened.

It is very important for organizations like OUR to intervene.  Whether one step or one child, there is a difference.  And if more collaborations are made within organizations and businesses and individuals and politicians and governments, I think it can stop.
It's going to be a long journey, but we believe in Andrew.  But most of all, Andrew believes in himself.
